name: Anjana ENSS

ABCDEFG HIJK LMNOP
QRST UV WXYZ ....
question_1:
Within the serene expanse of the campus, whether its cycling early in the morning or taking a stroll with friends in the night, there's always company - chirping of birds or the dogs. Conversations ranging from mundane to the profound life talks. From devouring Bhandara delights at the mandir premises to diving into events at Nalanda (and of course giving our own running commentary) or barging into the fun games, the thrill is real when the friends/ seniors(who are more like friends than seniors when it comes to fun) are in a mix. The seniors aren't just mentors, they're more like pals offering the best of both worlds - wisdom with a pinch of playfulness. 
I'll reminisce these cherished moments. These are like stubborn glitter from a party - bright, mess, annoying, and impossible to shake off.
question_2:
1. Sustainability Initiatives - Introducing recycling programs, reducing usage of plastic waste, and promoting eco-friendly practices to minimize campus's environmental footprint

2. Community Gardens - Establishing community gardens on campus where students, faculty and staff can come together to cultivate plants, explore diverse farming techniques and most importantly relish the experience together in open air.
While we do have the plantation drives - typically confined to a few weekends at the start of the monsoon. Having a year long initiative would be far more rewarding. It would provide a refreshing escape after or before a busy day on campus. 

3. Pets on campus: I acknowledge the gradual  utilization of the designated area for caretaking. But its imperative  to prevent them from entering the hostels and lab premises (POD buildings). Our furry friends may roam freely around the campus and frankly feels good as well (as long as they don't bite anyone), The moment they enter, they tend to scatter garbage from  trash cans, making the corridors dirty. and leaving trails of trash. Some measures to control this would be appreciated. 

4. Timely start of events: Many events on campus tend to start late. Most of us come from labs and have submissions/ deadlines hovering all the time and all of us usually get back to the as soon as the event concludes. So timely start would be greatly appreciated.

5. Addition of events: While most events are organized well and happen frequently, I would like to suggest scheduling classical/melody evenings, like the recent rendition to Rafi Saab, more regularly, perhaps every 3-4 months. These events offer unique dimension that appeals to a significant portion of the crowd, as many of us have a special corner for the classics and old songs apart from the rock/pop songs we listen and enjoy/ vibe on daily basis.

Last and something silly up next!
6. Introduction of Chat Bhandar: Please get one chat bhandar into the campus. The 99% crowd loves it, and it's such a big business that runs throughout the year, even in summers. Because when it comes to satisfying cravings, a chat bhandar is the ultimate flavor saver apart from ice-creams.

name: Shivani
about: Hello, I'm Shivani, a biology explorer with an insatiable curiosity for the natural world. Traveling holds a special place in my heart; I'm a multifaceted individual fueled by curiosity, creativity, and a profound appreciation for the wonders of life.
question_1: I will dearly miss the serene embrace of IIT Indore's nature in the tranquil hours of morning and evening. There's a special magic that unfolds during the lovely rainy season, transforming the campus into a breathtaking haven, where every droplet seems to dance in harmony with the lush greenery. The gentle mist that blankets the campus on winter mornings adds to its allure, shrouding everything in a mysterious yet enchanting veil. These moments of natural beauty have been more than just scenes to behold; they've been the backdrop to countless memories and moments of introspection. As I bid farewell, I carry with me the vivid images of these scenes, etched in my heart as cherished reminders of my time at IIT Indore.
question_2: Expanding food options and introducing more social activities can significantly enrich the experience and sense of community on campus

question_1: The 3 AM talks with bros. Meaningless, pointless banter that was sometimes intensely deep and depressing but always hid a layer of optimism and support, though sarcastically. It is never the big events; it is always about those normal days, the struggle to find tea, the endless queue at the night canteen, and quick bursts of laughter in between that seem so trivial but yet make up the largest chunk of beautiful memories. question_1: After graduating, I will undoubtedly miss the vibrant sense of community that enveloped me during my time at college. The opportunities for personal and intellectual growth, coupled with the invaluable connections forged with peers and mentors, have left an indelible mark on my journey. I'll cherish the structured environment and the abundance of resources that fueled my learning, as well as the feeling of being part of a supportive and inspiring community. Though I look forward to new adventures, I will always hold dear the memories and experiences that shaped my collegiate years.
question_2: In my vision for college, I'd prioritize upgrades to sports facilities to foster physical health and community engagement. A dynamic curriculum blending interdisciplinary learning and real-world applications would equip students with vital skills for the modern world. Ensuring food hygiene standards in dining facilities is essential for student health and wellness. Additionally, increasing the frequency of festivals and cultural events would enrich campus life, celebrate diversity, and foster inclusivity. Expanding mental health support services and promoting student involvement in decision-making processes would further enhance the overall well-being and engagement of the community. Embracing sustainability initiatives, investing in technology infrastructure, and fostering partnerships with local businesses would prepare students for success in the workforce while instilling values that contribute positively to society. These comprehensive changes aim to create a vibrant and supportive environment conducive to holistic student development, promoting academic success, personal growth, and overall well-being.

question_1: I will miss this carefree lifestyle and the unbound freedom. I'll be missing the casual meetups with my dear friends anytime and anywhere, those late night bakchodis, the last minute cramming before the exams, and the very interesting hall discussions in the flat, and the shared excitement before any event or plan. Infact I'll even be missing those trivial things that got so integrated in my life - that one electric port that doesn't work, that one tap which gives extremely hot water in summers, the doors without door stoppers, that common struggle for food when there is lauki ki sabzi in mess, that trip to daily needs after every meal‚Ä¶and so many more. But the thing that I will miss the most is that comfort of knowing that all my favourite people are just there, a few meters away, living the same life as me, having the same experiences and struggles as me.

name: Jaydeep Umarya
about: College life at IIT Indore has been a blast! It's not just about the campus; it's the awesome people who've made my journey unforgettable. From fun hangouts to learning , every interaction has been a treasure trove of inspiration. These amazing folks have shaped me into a better person, and I'll always cherish the good vibes and laughter we shared. Ready for new adventures, but I'll forever carry their influence with me.
question_1:
After graduating, I know I'll miss so many things about college life. It's been such an incredible journey with a lot of ups and downs . The people I've met, the experiences I've had, and the lessons I've learned have shaped me in ways I couldn't have imagined. There's something special about being surrounded by like-minded individuals who share your passions and interests. The vibe on campus is just unmatched ‚Äì every day is filled with opportunities for growth and improvement.

One of the things I'll miss the most is the sense of companionship that comes with working together towards a common goal, whether it's a team project or event. These collaborative efforts have taught me so much and have been some of the most rewarding experiences.

When I first arrived at IIT Indore, I was a different person, but over the years, I've learned to take full advantage of everything our college has to offer beyond academics. From exploring the beautiful campus life , building cool projects , to just enjoying early morning walks and witnessing the rays of sunshine, there's a sense of peace and rejuvenation that I'll miss that most .

And let's not forget about the amazing facilities ‚Äì from state-of-the-art labs to cozy libraries and everything in between, our campus truly has it all. But what truly makes it special are the passionate and hardworking people you meet along the way, whether it's through clubs or just striking up a conversation. These friendships have become invaluable to me, and I'll cherish them long after graduation. Plus, I'll miss those evenings spent hanging out with friends, going on tea breaks, and the mischief we got up to during college life  ‚Äì those memories will always bring a smile to my face.
question_2: One cool idea for implementing change in college would be to create more opportunities for interaction and collaboration among Batchmates. This could involve organizing regular group activities or workshops aimed at building personality traits like public speaking skills, teamwork, and leadership. Additionally, enhancing the greenery on campus by adding more beautiful plants and creating tranquil spaces could promote mental well-being and create a peaceful environment for students to thrive in.

name: NEERAJ NIKHIL
about: Hello! I'm Neeraj, a dedicated researcher and graduate student pursuing my Master of Science in Electrical Engineering at the prestigious Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Indore under prof. Vipul singh. With a keen interest in cutting-edge technology and a passion for solving complex problems, I am deeply immersed in my research focused on advancing the field of Nanotechnology and photodetectors.  Outside of academia, I enjoy staying active in the vibrant research community at IIT Indore, collaborating with fellow students and faculty on projects that push the boundaries of knowledge in my field. When I'm not in the lab or buried in research papers, you can find me unwinding with friends over a game of chess, exploring the scenic beauty of the campus, or indulging in my love for photography. I'm excited to continue my academic journey, contribute to groundbreaking research, and make a positive impact in the world of electrical engineering.

name: Prithwiraj Ganguly
about:
Hailing from a quaint small town, my journey of self-discovery over the past two years has been nothing short of transformative. Within this brief span of time, life has served as an exceptional teacher, imparting not only academic knowledge but also invaluable lessons in forging friendship across the diverse tapestry of India, fostering a deep appreciation for the cultural ethos of unity in diversity, and unveiling the profound beauty of collaborative research endeavors.

As I reflect on this chapter of my life, I am reminded that this is merely the prologue to a larger narrative, the prelude to an odyssey into the realms of the unknown.
question_1: The boundless flow of air on top of the POD 1A, my friends and their friendship.
question_2: As of my understanding, science is a culture which lies in the heart of discussion, collaboration and philosophy. Sometimes those ideas are buried under the intellectual thought process. If I would had enough power, I would like to make that to be more transparent.

question_1: I will miss this campus as a whole. Our classrooms, labs, sometimes intolerable food of mess. Late night entries, exploring pod terrace and staying there whole night with my friends in order to see the sunrise. Going in random seminars just to have that free ka samosa and chai. In winters having a tea on tea post with bornefire with a perfect combination of the song " Ye raate ye Mausam". And yaa in the first year going to the crush of my friends and ask them if they are single.
question_2:
Form the time we entered the college till the time we are getting farewell  construction is going on and on and on, so there should be a proper timeline for it.
